section.p: Biochar is a type of charcoal produced from organic materials, such as agricultural waste, wood chips, or crop residues, through a process called pyrolysis. Pyrolysis involves heating the organic material in the absence of oxygen, resulting in the production of a stable form of carbon-rich material known as biochar.

ul.li: Reduces the need for synthetic fertilizers

section.p: The process of making biochar involves heating organic materials in a low-oxygen environment, such as a kiln or pyrolysis reactor. This process converts the organic material into biochar while also producing byproducts such as bio-oil and syngas.
Biochar has diverse applications across various industries, including:

ul.li: Agriculture: Improving soil health and crop productivity
Environmental remediation: Filtering pollutants from water and air
Renewable energy: Generating bioenergy from biomass
Waste management: Converting organic waste into valuable products
